name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda Police Chief Paul Rolleri announced his retirement Wednesday in a decision that comes in the wake of a controversial arrest of a Black man who was dancing in the street. https://t.co/cdd4FJMipc

name: sfchronicle
text: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak is suing YouTube and its parent company Google, alleging the companies failed to take down videos using his likenesses in a Bitcoin scam. https://t.co/izWGI9aKuZ

name: sfchronicle
text: The Oakland City council voted Tuesday night against cutting another $11 million from the police budget, meaning OPD will lose $14.6 million in funding instead of $25 million. Read more: https://t.co/ntZ3kXAtKB

name: sfchronicle
text: With the 49ers scheduled to report to training camp Tuesday, here’s a review of the major summer stories by @Eric_Branch: https://t.co/37LZGFl5lU

name: sfchronicle
text:
Gabe Kapler era finally begins as #SFGiants and Dodgers open season. 

via @JohnSheaHey: https://t.co/LkwxcdYqoz

name: sfchronicle
text: “Smaller, closed spaces are more likely to facilitate transmission. But at the same time, smaller places have fewer people so even if transmission occurs, the number of people getting infected is also going to be small.” https://t.co/YwVm1fWctX

name: sfchronicle
text: A surge in COVID-19 cases at Santa Rita Jail in Dublin appears to be coming under control, officials said. https://t.co/P82cLSNoTH

name: sfchronicle
text:
Giants manager Gabe Kapler, with players and coaches, took a knee during the national anthem, and more followed them the next day.

This reinforced the Bay Area’s standing as the sports world’s leader in kneeling and political protest, writes @ScottOstler. https://t.co/50LPfcc4wM

name: sfchronicle
text: Four additional people died from COVID-19 in Alameda County, bringing the total to 171 deaths as of Wednesday, according to data compiled by The Chronicle. The county recorded five deaths the day before. https://t.co/89seBfiHml

name: sfchronicle
text: Have you been noticing more dreaded backups in the Bay Area? Data shows traffic has started picking back up again since the start of shelter-in-place — here's how close we are to "normal."  https://t.co/J1wM8NoWCW

name: sfchronicle
text:
Racial covenants were common in the U.S. during the 1930s and 1940s, embedded in property deeds as a way to keep nonwhite people from purchasing or occupying land. 

Why are home buyers in the Bay Area still finding them in housing documents? https://t.co/bC4UfaF3wq

name: sfchronicle
text: “I just don’t see a vaccine coming anytime soon,” said Nevan Krogan, a molecular biologist and director of UCSF’s Quantitative Biosciences Institute, which works in partnership with 100 research laboratories. https://t.co/IZIRarPx8x

name: sfchronicle
text: Giants manager Gabe Kapler, with players and coaches, took a knee during the national anthem, and more followed the… https://t.co/GJbcCor9Te

name: sfchronicle
text: Nopalito offering its beloved carnitas tacos in a take-out and delivery-only operation at a new Mission District location. Here are the details: https://t.co/pCCnmIhTHo

name: sfchronicle
text: As the pandemic surges and counties stumble through the start-stop process of reopening, the child care industry — a vital crutch for working parents — is facing financial ruin. https://t.co/PjKUwFdwJh

name: sfchronicle
text:
How much has highway traffic actually increased in the Bay Area since reopening began in May?

The short answer: We’re nearly three-quarters back to normal, depending on how you look at the data, @KellieHwang finds.

https://t.co/7srGbo2eXC

name: sfchronicle
text: “For far too long, organizations like the Sierra Club were complacent in a system where inequities prevailed,” Ramón Cruz said. “We won’t reach our environmental goals unless all of us ... keep putting (equity, inclusion and justice) front and center.” https://t.co/lyQvetWhWE

name: sfchronicle
text: The number of COVID-19 patients in California’s hospitals reached a record 7,170 people on Tuesday, state health officials report Wednesday. https://t.co/JCdYdabA3i

name: sfchronicle
text:
It was a bad day for California’s fight against the coronavirus. The state reported a record high amount of daily cases and surpassed New York for the highest number of cases in the country. 

Read more on the surging numbers: https://t.co/scb30v0aol https://t.co/6rLrbCmsO4

name: sfchronicle
text: Hardly Strictly Bluegrass plans to present Bay Area favorites @LosLobosBand for a live-streamed performance on July 25 — along with an update on 2020 festival plans. https://t.co/uzg8MEFP2l

name: sfchronicle
text: After years of deconstructing other people’s stories, YouTube star Lindsay Ellis is telling her own with “Axiom’s End,” an alien-contact novel set in California during the George W. Bush era. https://t.co/cV3boZENOT

name: sfchronicle
text: "While the Trader Joe’s thing is a little different, I think that the central issue at the heart of all this is that when any community isn't allowed control over their representation, harmful stereotypes and caricatures are allowed to be perpetuated." https://t.co/QI38glYUpO

name: sfchronicle
text: Generally speaking, the people at risk in indoor retail are probably not the customers but rather the employees, said Sally Picciotto, an associate researcher in environmental health at UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health. https://t.co/G1tlRkbrrJ

name: sfchronicle
text: Ever since people figured out how to transmute Silicon Valley’s home-brewed inventions into stock-market gold, there has been a steady business in monetizing Northern Californian optimism, writes @OwenThomas in this week's Tech Chronicle newsletter. https://t.co/OH35lFUsDi

name: sfchronicle
text: “For all the harms the Sierra Club has caused, and continues to cause, to Black people, indigenous people and other people of color, I am deeply sorry." https://t.co/46aYzXQdrb

name: sfchronicle
text:
“There’s nothing inherently better about a small space. A big space with fewer people would be less dangerous than a small space with more people."

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: JUST IN: Another 1.4 million Americans filed for unemployment last week, just as the benefits they can receive are about to drop by $600 a week. https://t.co/aZEhyV4IjY

name: sfchronicle
text: “We’ve gotten inured to levels of unemployment and furloughs we’ve never seen before in the U.S., that were unimaginable before the pandemic.” https://t.co/r4gPVbrY2h

name: sfchronicle
text: Traffic has started picking back up again on Bay Area highways as the region begins reopening. @KellieHwang takes a look at what’s happening on the roads: https://t.co/adzqvlyFdu

name: sfchronicle
text:
It’s @mlb Opening Day. Is this thing going to work? @susanslusser and @hankschulman join @demianbulwa to talk about baseball in a pandemic, @gabekapler kneeling, and how the 2020 @sfgiants and @Athletics are looking.
